entry.title: ABAP + MCP: Precise Answers from ABAP Keyword Documentation and other Best Practice Sources
entry.content:
This is a follow-up to my post about the SAP Documentation MCP Server. Since then, I have added a big ABAP-focused update and a practical guideline for formatting SAP Community posts. The goal stays the same: give you fast, grounded answers in your AI tools and make publishing smoother and predictable. My Blog Posts about MCP can be found here.

ABAP-first: What’s new in the SAP Docs MCP server

GitHub Repository: https://github.com/marianfoo/mcp-sap-docs 

The server now bundles the official ABAP Keyword Documentation as files, the SAP Clean ABAP style guide and the DSAG ABAP Leitfaden for clean-core development, plus real showcase projects such as the ABAP Platform Fiori Feature Showcase (RAP/OData V4) and the CAP Fiori Elements showcase. ABAP search is fully integrated into the standard sap_docs_search interface (same as UI5, CAP, and wdi5) with intelligent version handling: latest by default, or targeted when you include versions like 7.57 in your query. Results are curated for quality with rich snippets and official source links.

Try it quickly

Hosted endpoints: SSE and Streamable HTTP. Full background and client setup are in my original article: Feed SAP Help, UI5 APIs & SAP Community Content into your AI with this Open Source MCP Server. For Eclipse specifics and Copilot notes, see the README section: Eclipse + GitHub Copilot. Unfortunately GitHub Copilot is not yet supported in Agent Mode with MCP Server (see GitHub Issue)

ABAP dev setup: VS Code

The official path is Eclipse with ABAP Development Tools (ADT). As this is not yet supported let´s do this in VS Code.

Start with ABAP remote filesystem (abapfs) to connect VS Code directly to your ABAP system and work on server objects. It’s less capable than ADT but very responsive and includes neat extras like listing changed sources by transport, normalizing diffs, where‑used, transport handling, short‑dump views, integrated abapGit/test explorer, and even a debugger. Pair it with abaplint for VS Code for syntax highlighting and static checks. If you work heavily with annotations, install an ABAP CDS language support extension as well (for example, ABAP CDS Language Support).

A minimal quick start with abapfs looks like this:

# 1) Ensure ADT ICF is active (SICF: /sap/bc/adt)
# 2) In VS Code install "ABAP remote filesystem" and run:
#    Command Palette -> "ABAPfs: Create connection" then "ABAPfs: Connect to an ABAP system"
# 3) Use the ABAPfs explorer to open packages, create objects, and activate

Once you have set it up, you can use the data with any model and the MCP server and edit ABAP and RAP models.

Search ABAP (one standard tool)

All ABAP queries use sap_docs_search. General questions return the latest ABAP content plus related sources; adding a version like 7.57 narrows results to that specific version.

{
  "tool": "sap_docs_search",
  "query": "inline declarations"
}

Version-targeted:

{
  "tool": "sap_docs_search",
  "query": "LOOP 7.57"
}

Retrieve a specific document with the standard getter:

{
  "tool": "sap_docs_get",
  "library_id": "/abap-docs-latest/abeninline_declarations"
}

Claude.ai

Of course, this works in any LLM client such as Claude. ABAP is available through the same standard interface (sap_docs_search / sap_docs_get) — no special tools required. If you already added the remote server, nothing else is needed.
See the conversation here: https://claude.ai/share/6ec2a83a-da6e-4505-9af8-73d72f64adad 

Wrap-up

The ABAP additions to the MCP server make answers fast and precise by serving small, source‑attributed documents first. Search is unified via sap_docs_search with intelligent version handling (latest by default, targeted when specified), and results are curated with rich snippets and official links. Use ADT for the fully supported experience, or VS Code with abapfs + abaplint (+ CDS support) when you prefer a lightweight editor. And when you publish, stick to the allowed HTML subset for clean rendering.

Hi @Soundarya06 

I understand you wanted to explore how to make KFs editable and other KF not editable right? If so, when marking a query as editable = checked, inside the query elements on your desired KFs you can individually mark then as Yes or No. This way, even if the query is editable you have an option to make a specific KF as no so it wont be editable and others are if they set as Yes.

I hope this helps!

entry.title: Re: SDA Connectivity with MSSQL - Authentication Options
entry.content:
Hi,

Starting from Microsoft ODBC Driver 18, the encrypt connection property is enabled by default and supports SSL connections.
This means that TLS encryption is also enabled for connections to older versions of Microsoft SQL Server databases that use Microsoft ODBC Driver 18 with the default setting.
Additionally, 'Managing Single Sign-On (SSO) with Kerberos' is only applicable when the remote source is SAP HANA 2.0 Platform Edition (on-premise). This is not supported when the remote source is Microsoft SQL Server.
In that sense, please adapt the answer accordingly.

Best,
Seungjoon

entry.title: SAP Datasphere News in August
entry.content:
SAP Datasphere News in August

Another month with two nice new release deliveries ✨

Learn more in my short top features video in August 2025 on YouTube 📺

In addition, explore the latest updates in our community news blogs and more.

 

 

My top features in August

 

Transformation Flow: Processing in Batches

You can now break down large transformation flow datasets into batches to avoid out-of-memory (OOM) errors when using the SAP HANA runtime in Datasphere. Defining batches on transformation flows enhances the performance and reliability, while ensuring efficient data integration and processing.

You find this feature in the data integration monitor as it is part of the runtime settings under the Batches tab. Simply pick a suitable column and define the batch sizes in number or records. You can also define to use it only for a large initial load or both initial and delta loads.

➡️  More information.

 

New source and targets for Replication Flows

Microsoft OneLake as a Source for Your Replication Flow

You can now use Microsoft OneLake—which was formerly also known as Azure Data Lake Generation 2—, and the corresponding connection type to add sources to replication flows and replicate data in CSV format from the source for initial loads.

➡️  More information.

  • Cloud Storage Provider Sources
  • Microsoft OneLake Connections

 

SAP Signavio as Target for Your Replication Flows

You can now use connection type SAP Signavio and replication flows to load data from SAP source systems, such as SAP S/4HANA and others, into SAP Signavio as target system. This allows an efficient and scalable data replication into the SAP Signavio solution.

➡️  More information.

  • SAP Signavio Targets
  • SAP Signavio Connections

 

SAP Analytics Cloud, add-in for Microsoft Excel

There is a very nice feature new in SAP Analytics Cloud, which I think is super useful for many of you. With the QRC 3 release, you can transfer a table from an SAC story to Excel and further use it with the add-in. In Excel, the transferred table is based on the same data source, for example Datasphere, and has the same navigation state (dimensions, measures in rows and columns, filters, and variables). The idea is to benefit from native Excel capabilities on Datasphere data in real time. You can adjust the report, add custom functions on top of the table, and more.

➡️  More information.

 



SAP Business Data Cloud Getting Started Series

 

Starting September 10, the Getting Started Series kicks off with three modules

  • Module 1: Build an Intelligent Application Grounded in Data Products (Sep 10, 2025)
  • Module 2: Fuel AI Innovation with SAP Databricks in Business Data Cloud (Sep 24, 2025)
  • Module 3: Create and Enrich an Analytical Model with SAP Datasphere (Oct 8, 2025)

👉  Sign up today on the registration page.

➡️  Step-By-Step Guide: Getting started with the SAP Business Data Cloud Basic Trial

 

Learning Update

Our learning colleagues are currently defining a brand new course: Becoming an SAP Data Architect.

You will learn:

🔹How Data Architecture enables efficiency, innovation, and measurable business outcomes

🔹 Ways to communicate complex data concepts clearly — to both technical and non-technical stakeholders

🔹 How to identify and prioritize opportunities, build business cases, and articulate value

🔹 Techniques for designing target-state architectures aligned with SAP Business Data Cloud, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Datasphere

🔹 Storytelling methods to overcome resistance and foster adoption of data-driven change

 

This course is the first step in a learning path:

✅  Start with the free “Becoming an SAP Data Architect” course in November 2025

✅  Continue with a free advanced course coming early 2026

🏆  Together, they prepare you for a brand-new SAP Data Architect certification in 2026

 

My favorite blogs in August

 

Use SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Estimator

There is a great blog series about the capacity estimator SAP Business Data Cloud, which of course also includes the SAP Datasphere estimator by @FernandaFroelich. Not all blogs are published yet as the series is work in progress, but already a great start:

  1. Learn How to use SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator?
  2. Explore How to edit a quota assignment in SAP Business Data Cloud?
  3. Use the Capacity Unit Estimator across SAP Analytics Cloud, SAP Datasphere, and SAP Databricks. 

 

SAP Business Data Cloud rewiring of existing Datasphere and SAC tenants

My dear colleague @Ammar_Naji has updated his blog on the rewiring option for existing SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud tenants. Very informative and includes all the steps which need to be done.

➡️  UPDATE: SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud Availability via SAP Business Data Cloud

 

Open Resource Directory

This is a must read for all SAP Business Data Cloud experts out there:
➡️  Why we created Open Resource Discovery

The Open Resource Discovery (ORD) is the core protocol for application / service metadata publishing and discovery within SAP Business Data Cloud. This blog written by @SimonHeimler explains the concepts behind the scenes and gives you links to resources where you find further details.

 

SAP Datasphere SQL Navigator browser plugin

SAP Mentor and active community member @kostertim has created a very useful browser plugin to be able to navigate from one SQL view to another by just highlighting the view and using a hotkey combination or browser context menu—avoiding a lot of copy-and-paste efforts. All is described in his blog ➡️  DSP SQL Navigator – Stop copy pasting URLs! And of course the YouTube video:

entry.title: Installation, Migration , Uninstallation Of MAXDB 7.9 and content Server 7.5
entry.content:
Introduction :

Blog provides step by step procedure to perform migration of SAP MaxDB Content Server 6.4 from windows server 2003 to SAP MaxDB Content Server 7.5 Windows server 2022 using online backup/restore method by creating a standby database. It is focusing on a method to reduce downtime during MaxDB Content Server migration of large database. This is needed for systems which are highly critical to get downtime for migration purpose from customer.

SUMMARY : 

This blog outlines a step-by-step process to migrate SAP MaxDB Content Server from version 6.4 on Windows Server 2003 to version 7.5 on Windows Server 2022 using the online backup/restore method. The approach involves creating a standby database to minimize downtime, making it ideal for critical systems where extended downtime is not feasible.

System Overview:


Source System:

  • MaxDB version: 7.6.11
  • Content Server 6.4

 

  • Server: Windows Server 2003.



Target system:

  • MaxDB version : 7.9.10.5
  • Content Server 7.5

 

  • Server: Windows Server 2022



Migration Method: Online Backup/Restore

Backup Tool: Database Studio

DB Size: 250 GB

 

 

 

Preparation:

 

  1. Install Content Server 7.5 on the target server

  2. Install MAXDB 7.9.10.5 on the target Server

     

    Installation of Content Server 7.5

    Perform the installation of SAP Content Server 7.5 instance on target server (Windows Server 2023) using SWPM.

    Overview :

    1. Content Server 7.5 is a standalone application which can use MAXDB as a storage and Filesystem as a storage. As of content Server 6.5 , you can install content Server 6.5 and MAXDB 7.9 in one step but in Content Server 7.5 , you need to install Content Server 7.5 and MAXDB 7.9 as a different instance. You have to  install Content Server 7.5 and then MAXDB 7.9.

    2. Content Server 6.5 doesn't have any SID while content Server 7.5 is having SID which makes it easy to integrate the system for monitoring purpose. 

    3. Content Server 6.5 is compatible in windows 2019 as per PAM while content Server 7.5 is compatible for all windows server as well as all NetWeaver version whether it is NetWeaver 7.0.

    4. Content Server 6.5 needs IIS configuration while its not required in installation of content Server 7.5

     

     


     

    Perform the installation of Content Server 7.5 instance on target server (Windows Server 2022) using SWPM 1.0 latest SP.

     

    changed sapcs to /ContentServer/ContentServer.dll and configure HTTP port to 1290

     

    Perform the installation of MAXDB 7.9 instance on target server (Windows Server 2022) using SWPM 1.0 latest SP

     

  3. In Unix it will ask for SAR file 

 

  1. Cutover Plan for the Migration from MAXDB 7.6 to MAXDB 7.9

     

    Master Note : 2786364 - SAP Content Server and Cache Server 7.5 (and higher) 

    Now the question comes in mind if we can use the backup restore method to migrate the MAXDB 7.6 to MAXDB 7.9. The answer is yes but source and target system should be unicode.

     

    1. Stop the SAP application so that no one can upload the documents on the content Server

     

    2. Take complete backup from old MAXDB 7.6 and move the backup to new server.

    3. Recover the database in MAXDB 7.9

     

    4. Now change the password of SUPERDBA user to the same password which you used during installation as new password came from the source system and run the load_systab

     

    Check in content server URL is working or giving the error. Below error will solve once you change the password for SUPERDBA user.

     

    Make change in OAC0.

     

    Go to OAC0 , Now give HTTP server to target server
    Give HTTP port 1290 difined during installation
    Ensure firwall is enabled between SAP Application Server and Target Content Server
    Click on Exchange certificate and do the connection test
    Now go to csadmin . It will promt for password you need to give password of content server sidadm and password
    Certificate : Send the certificate and activate it
    Setting :
    ContentStorageHost : target host
    StorageDrive : SAPDBStorage
    Security : 1
    ContentStorageName : CPX
    ContentStorageDriver : SAP MAXDB CPX(Unicode)

    Save it

     

    You may encounter the error 

    To fix the issue follow : 2141940 - Database Repositories adjustment when upgrading to SAP Content Server 6.4. Note contains one script cs650prep.sql which will fix issue from migrating date from content Server 6.5 to 7.5 . You need to run the script in target MAXDB 7.9 database studio or command prompt.

     

    After that this issue will be fixed.

     

    Now verify the availability of the new Content Server

    You can run reports RSCMSTH0, RSCMSTH1 and RSCMSTH2 to check the new installation. Additionally, functional tests should be performed to verify that repositories and documents can be accessed normally.

     

    Now you can handover the system to customer after shutdown the old content Server for testing.

     

     

    Uninstalling the old Content Server and MAXDB Instance

    You can uninstall using SWPM but sometimes you can encounter the error for which you need to delete the windows registry entry and also uninstall packages from control panel -> uninstall program

     

    Control Panel -> uninstall program

     

    SUMMARY

    This blog outlines a step-by-step process to migrate SAP MaxDB Content Server from version 6.4 on Windows Server 2003 to version 7.5 on Windows Server 2022 using the online backup/restore method. The approach involves creating a standby database to minimize downtime, making it ideal for critical systems where extended downtime is not feasible.

    Thanks for reading my post.

entry.title: Re: gCTS - Backup and Restore specific ABAP Object - Git
entry.content:
Hi,
gCTS does not offer any kind of cherry picking. You can activate any commit in the list of commits and therewith any software state that you had in the past. Details are described in here https://help.sap.com/docs/ABAP_PLATFORM_NEW/4a368c163b08418890a406d413933ba7/2af3e9477392441e80651339352acdc1.html 
Allowing the restore of single objects could cause many issues as you cannot recover a single object - many objects in a git repository might have dependencies and just activating one of them could result in a not working application. We therefore only allow activating software states represented by a certain commit.

Kind regards
Karin

entry.title: Migration SAP PI/PO to SAP Cloud Integration using Pipeline concepts
entry.content:
Dear SAP consultants:

I have been working on migrating from SAP PI/PO to SAP Cloud Integration, and I would like to share my experience with the Pipeline concept introduced by SAP for migration projects. Since there are not many blogs or discussions on this topic, I thought it would be helpful to share my experience.

Let’s quickly recap SAP PI/PO. In PI/PO, we usually create common IDOC and proxy channels to connect SAP ERP with the PI/PO system for both outbound and inbound communication. A single IDOC & Proxy channel can be reused across multiple flows/scenarios. If needed, we can also create multiple IDOC channels using the same destination in SM59. However, this approach doesn’t work the same way in SAP Cloud Integration. One HTTP destination can’t be used for multiple flow.

Example: if there are 100 IDOC flows from SAP ERP to SAP Cloud Integration, we need to create 100 separate HTTP destinations - each one mapped to its corresponding iFlow endpoint. Unlike PI/PO, where a single destination could be reused, SAP CI requires a unique destination per flow.

I believe this was the initial perspective of most SAP PI/PO consultants, but with SAP’s continuous support, better approaches are being discovered day by day.
Since we all started the migration journey some time ago, there are many ways to handle the IDOC and proxy scenarios.
However, one of the best ways to use the Pipeline concept for Asynchronous Pattern.

I will try to explain in simple terms.

  1. We require to use the Standard Pipeline Template provided by SAP.

  2. JMS queues  for retry mechanism. 
  3. Partner Directory setup  for each IDOC/proxy flow.

Let’s discuss end to end Outbound IDOC scenario to understand more.

1. We require to use the Standard Pipeline Template provided by SAP: 

Copy the Standard Package  “Process Integration Pipeline - Generic Integration Flows & Templates“


Deploy the below highlighted iFlows.

Pipeline Generic - Script Collection: Deploy the common scripts collection package will be used across the pipeline steps.

Step 01: Pipeline Generic Step01 - Inbound Processing for Idoc
Deploy and use end point of this iFlow in HTTP destination created in SAP system.
So, the connection established and when IDOC triggered – it will point to this flow.
Basically, this flow will receive the IDOC from SAPERP and send to JMS Queue PIPQ01. 

Step 02: Pipeline Generic Step02 - Inbound Processing
The flow will pick the messages from first JMS queue PIPQ01 and run through flow by determining the partner ID which is created in Partner directory. (will discuss this part below) then will drop to JMS queue PIPQ02.
If any issue occurs during this flow, it will be go back to PIPQ01_DLQ(first flow dead letter queue) after max retries.

Step 03: Pipeline Generic Step04 - Receiver Determination
This step to find the receiver using XSLT mapping maintained in Partner directory. We will have to prepare the XSLT mapping and define the condition, upload it partner directory.
The flow will pick the messages from second JMS queue PIPQ02 and run through the iFlow to check the receiver --> then drop the message to JMS queue PIPQ03.
If any issue occurs, receiver determination step failed them it will be moved to last step dead letter queue after retries i.e PIPQ02_DLQ.

Step 04: Pipeline Generic Step05 - Interface Determination
Again in the same way, the Integration flow will pick the messages from third JMS queue PIPQ03 and find interface mapping path and drop the messages to last fourth queue PIPQ04.
If this iFlow fails with issue then message moved back to last step Dead letter queue i.e PIPQ03_DLQ

Step 05: Pipeline Generic Step06 - Outbound Processing
Outbound processing step will pick the message from JMS queue PIPQ04 and identify the next iFlow. (based on process direct adapter path) and send messages to corresponding iFlow.
If this iFlow fails with issue then message moved back to last step Dead letter queue i.e PIPQ04_DLQ

Step 06: (scenario specific flow- you can use custom names)
In this flow Mapping conversion and connection to receiver. We have SAP provided templates as well for this step, however I haven’t used them. Created own custom Integration flow to handle the mapping and connection to receiver.
If any issue occurs the message will be failed status and message processing is then retried from the last integration flow.

  • We can migrate/import mapping from SAP PO ESR to custom last step iFlow. 
  • The process direct adapter channel path should match the one defined in the interface determination mapping.

 

Below table summarizes  all pipeline steps and how the integration flow works: 

 

2. JMS queues required for retry mechanism:

Required total 8 JMS queues. 4 normal queues and 4 dead letter queues to handle the retry mechanism.

(PIPQ01, PIPQ01_DLQ, PIPQ02, PIPQ02_DLQ, PIPQ03, PIPQ03_DLQ, PIPQ04, PIPQ04_DLQ)

Once we deploy the above standard SAP iFlows - the below JMS queues will automatically created.

3. Partner Directory:

Create the PID for each interface.
PID is combination of sender system and sender interface name
Example: SAPCLNT100~ORDERS.ORDERS05
               <sendersystem>~<senderInterfacename>



Entity Type: String Parameter: we use this parameter to maintain the JMS retries count.
ID: MaxJMSRetries
Value: 3 or 4, If message fails in any pipeline step based on this value, it retries count intervals.

Binary Parameter: we use this parameter to upload the xsl mapping code for receiver and interface determination.
ID = receiverDetermination
ID = interfaceDetermination_<ReceiverName>
Create the XSLT mapping for both receiver determination and interface determination and upload.

Whatever the receivername you maintained in the receiver determination, will be automatically taken that name in interfaceDetermination_"Receivername" – so use the same name in ID. Else it will be failed with error.

Sample XSLT code for receiver determination:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<xsl:stylesheet version="3.0" xmlns:xsl="http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform">
    <xsl:template match="/">
        <ns0:Receivers xmlns:ns0="http://sap.com/xi/XI/System">
            <xsl:choose>
                <xsl:when test="/ORDERS05/IDOC/EDI_DC40/RCVPRN = 'Germany'">
                    <Receiver>
                        <Service>GermanyBMW</Service>
                    </Receiver>
                </xsl:when>
                <xsl:otherwise>
                    <Receiver>
                        <Service>NotDefined</Service>
                    </Receiver>
                </xsl:otherwise>
            </xsl:choose>
        </ns0:Receivers>
    </xsl:template>
</xsl:stylesheet>

sample XSLT code for interface determination:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<xsl:stylesheet version="3.0" xmlns:xsl="http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform">
  <xsl:template match="/">
    <ns0:Interfaces xmlns:ns0="http://sap.com/xi/XI/System">
      <Interface>
        <Index>1</Index>
        <Service>Integration_Mapping_Step_and_Connection_to_Receiver_Step07</Service>
      </Interface>
    </ns0:Interfaces>
  </xsl:template>
</xsl:stylesheet>


Alternative Partners
Agency: SenderSystem Name (SAPERP)
Scheme: SenderInterface
ID: SenderInterfaceName

The same way we can add more entries in partner directory for different interfaces.

ex: SAPCLNT100~SHPMNT.SHPMNT06
       SAPCLNT100~CustomerData_Out
       etc...

Testing:

We are ready to test now. Let's do it.

I have triggered test IDOC from ERP and below is the message flow of all pipeline steps handled.

I hope this provides useful insights into migration from SAP PI/PO to Cloud Integration for handling IDOC asynchronous scenarios.

Advantages:

  • Design: Pipeline steps break down integration flow into clear, manageable steps (ex: sender, processing, receiver). This makes it easier to design, debug, and maintain integration scenarios.
  • Re-try mechanisms. Since all pipeline steps decoupled, JMS queues handle the automatic retry to process if the messages fail.
  • Monitoring: Each pipeline step can be monitored individually, helping identify bottlenecks or failures quickly.
  • Easy Migration: We  just needed to import the mapping from SAP PO - everything else is already available in the pipeline template to complete the integration.

Reference: Fully Decoupled Pipeline 

 

Regards,
Sathish Kumar B P 
SAP Integration Developer

entry.title: Re: Deleting rows based on other rows - Data Action
entry.content:
@andreag412 For Option 1 , I think you want to delete the data where currency is not the same as Local currency of the market. In your sample data its CNY for Market CN. If your market dimension has an attribute for currency with value CN, the below sample Data Action logic can work. For both Option 1 and 2 Assumption is Currency attribute in MARK is set to CNY

MEMBERSET [d/DATASOURCE]="ADD"
IF [d/MARK].[p/Currency] != [d/CC].[p/id] THEN
  DELETE()
ENDIF

For Option 2 

MEMBERSET [d/DATASOURCE]="INP"
MEMBERSET [d/CC]="#"

DATA([d/CC]=[d/MARK].[p/Currency])=RSEULTLOOKUP([d/CC]="#")

 

Hope this helps !!

Nikhil

entry.title: Re: MIGO Error
entry.content:
Check the following:-

  • In PO History tab, check whether the entire quantity has already been inwarded
  • If the item is set Deletion indicator in PO, it wont appear in MIGO

entry.title: Re: Extra line items with zero value in settlement document
entry.content:
Hello,

The cause of this could be due to incorrect configuration of the split criteria for settlement in the profile for business volume determination for the condition contract. The system tries to match up accruals from WCOCOF with settlement line items. This is where the configuration in field "Field name accruals reversal split" becomes important. You can try to debug method GET_ACCRUALS (CL_WB2_REBATE_SETTLEMENT) to see why these incorrect lines get added to the settlement document.

Thanks

entry.title: Re: Need API to Trigger Outbound Payment Status After Ban...
entry.content:
Hi Mahavir

Based on the details provided, you are describing a classic integration after bank statement posting use case. Let’s break it down and give you a Public Cloud aligned answer.

The following are the key Points from your described scenario

  • Inbound: Invoices are posted from a third-party system into S/4HC.
  • Payment: Process runs in S/4HC, reconciliation is done with BANK_STATEMENT_POST_IN.
  • Requirement: As soon as invoices are cleared by the bank statement, push the Paid or Cleared status goes back to the third-party system automatically.
  1. Here are some business events in public cloud

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud provides business events that can be consumed in SAP Event Mesh or via SAP Integration Suite.

For your particular case:

  • When bank statements are posted, the actual FI clearing happens through Accounting Document clearing.
  • Moving forward you should look at the Journal Entry Cleared (JournalEntry.Cleared) and the Supplier Invoice Cleared (SupplierInvoice.Cleared) due to their relevance to your scenario. These are published as Enterprise Events in S/4HC → BTP Event Mesh → can trigger your outbound interface.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Events

  1. APIs to Read Status
  • You are correct, BusinessPartnerPaymentStatus API allows you to query open/cleared items.
  • Alternatively, Journal Entry Read or Supplier Invoice API can also provide cleared status. But APIs are pull-based and you will have to schedule jobs to fetch cleared items.
  1. The recommended extension strategy is to combine Business Events with APIs: Subscribe to SupplierInvoice.Cleared or JournalEntry.Cleared event, trigger your iFlow or CAP app when the event is raised, use the API to enrich details such as invoice number, amount and status. Finally push the status to your third-party system. This ensures event-driven push without custom BAdIs in core.
  2. If No Suitable Event exists, sometimes, bank statement specific events are not directly published.
  • If that is the case then:
    • Use Custom CDS View plus Custom Business Object to collect cleared items after BANK_STATEMENT_POST_IN.
    • Expose it as a custom outbound API and schedule it via Communication Arrangement
  • Please note that the preferred option is Enterprise Events, as this is SAP’s clean-core strategy in Public Cloud.

I hope this provides the desired result. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: TO CARRYFORWARD SPECIFIC MEASURES TO THE NEW APPROVAL YEAR
entry.content:
Business Scenario:

  • A new approval year (2025) was created by copying the 2024 Investment Program.
  • A new project/WBS was created and assigned to the 2024 IM Program.
  • The business now wants to include only specific WBS elements in the 2025 IM Program.

 

Steps to Carry Forward Specific WBS:

  1. Transaction Code: IM27_REPEAT
  2. Input:
    • Investment Program Name
    • Source Approval Year: 2024
    • Target Approval Year: 2025 (Auto populate)

3. Command Input: Type =DELTA in the command field.

 

4. Selection Options:

  • Example: D1.11166.1
    • Uncheck all options except WBS Elements (If the budget of the IM node needs to be carried forward, ensure the checkbox for 'Carry forward budget values' is selected).
    • Enter the specific WBS element(s) to be carried forward.

 

5. Execute the Transaction.

6. Verification:

    • Use transaction code IM12 / IM 13 to verify the IM assignments.

Before:

 

After:

 

Outcome:

This process allows you to assign individual measures (WBS elements) to the new IM Program year without affecting the entire structure and based on the requirement ensures that budgets and planned values are carried forward appropriately.

entry.title: The Smart Path to S/4HANA EWM
entry.content:
Overview of the current four solutions

There are currently four SAP solutions to help you manage your warehouse: Stockroom Management; Warehouse Management; EWM Basic; and EWM Advanced. Below, we’ll look at the differences between them. Note that there will be no further development of the first two, as SAP is positioning EWM on S/4HANA as the strategic choice going forward. Its key benefits include:

  • Better warehouse performance
  • Complete process and stock transparency
  • Preconfigured best practice content
  • Clear roadmap of future developments
  • Supported by latest technologies and continuous innovation
  • Scalability and flexible extension options
  • Lowest TCO

Can Stockroom Management replace a transition to EWM?

You probably know that SAP introduced SAP Stockroom Management in 2020, running on S/4HANA. This solution is helpful for small warehouses with predominantly manual processes that only require a few basic functions, such as storage bin management. However, it isn’t suited to industrial companies looking to streamline their logistical processes across the board. For example, Stockroom Management doesn’t include functions such as task and resource management; value-added services; cross-docking; picking waves; or WM-LSR. As noted above, this product will not be developed any further.

Choosing the right EWM solution for you

Now that we’ve established that most companies will likely want to transition to EWM, let’s look at the options available. In terms of the solutions embedded in S/4HANA, you can choose between EWM Basic Warehousing and EWM Advanced Warehousing, for which an additional license is required.  If you prefer a decentralized solution, SAP offers the extended cloud variant of EWM as well as the decentralized version on S/4HANA. It’s important for companies to look into the features and functions they need for their processes and what could be dropped. Here’s an overview to make your selection easier.

 

 

Overview of features and functions in SAP WM offerings

SDT: the optimal migration approach for EWM

Unlike an ECC to S/4HANA transition, migrating to EWM is a little more complex in that the previous system was part of SCM as opposed to ECC. As such, a classic brownfield migration using automatic system conversion isn’t available. One solution would be to start from scratch with a new system (greenfield), although this involves redesigning your processes. Selective data transformation is clearly the better option here, as it enables you to reuse your business and historical data while updating your existing processes. This migration concept is available from SAP as well as its SDT partners: Natuvion, cbs, and SNP.  These offer specialized migration and mapping tools that accelerate the process of data analysis, selection, and verification.

The importance of dealing with transactional data

Customers using EWM 9.x can use the SAP Migration Cockpit to move to S/4HANA, although the cockpit doesn’t handle transactional data, cross-client customizing or user authentication so companies would need to look after those aspects themselves or work with their SAP SDT partner. If they are unable to leave the old transactional data behind, they could use SAP’s SDT partners’ tools to transfer it to the central control system, then to map and update the transactional data prior to migrating it to the new EWM system.

Deciding what to migrate and what to archive

Many companies find the process complex as they often use highly specialized processes, making it difficult to decide what to transfer and what to leave behind. In addition, there may be legal considerations such as a requirement to retain data for a certain number of years. SAP and its SDT partners can assist with this process, particularly with regard to reducing the size of the database to be migrated. S/4HANA databases can be expensive to maintain if they are large and continue to grow. Archiving solutions are available that enable you to keep and access the old data for auditing and research purposes, while only transferring currently useful data. This approach offers big benefits in terms of cost and performance for the new system while preserving and protecting the historical data.

Three key aspects to consider before starting an EWM migration

 

  • The first elementto consider is dealing with the custom code – repository objects – as many warehouses have very specific hardware and structures. The Custom Code Impact Analysis service can help here, as it highlights whether and how this data will be affected by the move to the new infrastructure.
  • The second aspectis closing the old documents. A prerequisite of S/4HANA is that docs are closed before being moved. Yet some documents can’t be closed, especially quality inspection documents and others that have to be open all the time. The SDT approach helps here as it will move both open and closed documents. This applies whether you’re choosing the embedded or the decentralized SAP EWM solution.
  • Last but not least, downtime.Greenfield projects require several shorter downtime incidences, while SDT usually only requires one. Near-zero downtime may not be possible given the specificities of warehouse systems, but the right tools, like those offered by the SAP SDT partners can make a significant contribution to reducing the impact on business continuity.

 

Decentralized option for better performance

SAP and its SDT partners have estimated that 90-95% of their customers decide on a decentralized EWM system on S/4HANA in preference to the embedded variant. This is because it’s the strategic platform and more future-proof from a data volume perspective, especially for customers with large databases and warehouse systems.  In addition, if someone else in your company is doing some heavy-duty data extraction on the ERP system, there may be a slowdown effect on an EWM embedded in the ERP system that would not arise with a decentralized option.

Talk to us!

Despite the complexities of moving from an SCM-based solution to EWM on S/4HANA, SAP and its SDT partners have the tools and experience to smooth the path for its customers. Feel free to contact us to find out more.

For further information you can also have a look into our webinar "SDT - how to deal with other SAP suite solutions? Focus: EWM".

entry.title: Service Entry Sheet Accruals - Posting and Configurations for SAP S/4HANA 2023
entry.content:
1.  Overview

In SAP S/4HANA, a Service Entry Sheet (SES) is used to confirm that services ordered through a purchase order have been rendered by the vendor. Once accepted, the SES triggers the posting of a service receipt in the system, which serves as the basis for vendor invoicing and financial postings.

Accruals in the context of SES ensure that expenses for services received but not yet invoiced are recognized in the correct accounting period. This is critical for accurate period-end closing, aligning with accrual-based accounting principles. In SAP S/4HANA, the system can automatically generate accrual postings for unbilled services, recording them in GR/IR (Goods Receipt/Invoice Receipt) or specific accrual accounts, depending on configuration.

The process typically involves:

  1. Creation of Purchase Order (PO) for services.
  2. Entry of Service Entry Sheet and Send for Approval
  3. Automatic Posting for Accrual at period-end for unapproved SES items.

With the Service Entry Sheet Accrual, organizations benefit from:

  • Embedded Fiori apps for SES creation, approval, and accrual management.
  • Integration with Finance (FI) and Materials Management (MM) modules for seamless tracking.
  • Real-time reporting capabilities to monitor open SES accruals.
  • Compliance with IFRS/GAAP through precise period-based expense recognition.

This functionality ensures financial accuracy, enhances transparency, and supports audit readiness by maintaining a clear link between service receipt, accrual recognition, and final settlement.

2.  Posting of Service Entry Sheet Accruals – Overview

Steps to Create Service Entry Sheet Accrual

  1. Create Service Purchase Order
    • Use the Fiori app “Manage Purchase Orders” or transaction ME21N.
    • Select Document Type for service procurement (e.g., NB).
    • Enter vendor, service item category (Standard or E), and service specifications.
    • Maintain service conditions, quantities, and delivery dates.
    • Save the PO to generate the PO number.
  2. Create Service Entry Sheet
    • Use Fiori app “Manage Service Entry Sheets”
    • Reference the PO number.
    • Enter the service lines, quantities, and any notes.
    • Confirm the services are delivery date according to the PO.
  3. Send Service Entry Sheet for Approval
    • Initiate approval via workflow (configured in Flexible Workflow for SES).
  4. Display Service Entry Sheet Accruals
    • Use Fiori app “Display Journal Entries – Accruals” or Manage Accruals – Purchase Orders.
    • Filter by SES, PO, or accounting period.
    • Review the accrual calculation.
  5. Post Service Entry Sheet Accruals

Post Periodic Entries for Service Entry Sheet Accruals

  • Open the Schedule Accrual Jobs Fiori app.
  • Select the predefined job template “Post Periodic Entries for Service Entry Sheet Accrual”.
  • Enter parameters such as Company Code, Fiscal Year/Period, and relevant filters.
  • Turn off Test Run to post actual entries.
  • Execute or schedule the job for period-end
  • The system posts accruals for unapproved Service Entry Sheet, ensuring proper expense recognition in the correct accounting period.

2.1.   Service Purchase Order

In Order to create SES Accruals, Service Purchase Order with Standard Document Type (NB) and Account Assignment needs to be created.

 

P.S:

  1. SES works only for Standard Purchase Order Type (NB)
  2. Item Category should be blank(standard) or E (Limit)
  3. Product Category should be “2” for Services

2.2.   Create Service Entry Sheet

Service Entry Sheet should be created from the Service Purchase Order. Accrual Engine will pick up only Service entry sheet which has document status “In Approval”.

 

 

 

 

P.S:

  1. Service Entry Sheet Should be created in Fiori

2.3.   Display Service Entry Sheet Accruals

Once the SES sent for approval accrual object and accrual will be created automatically.

 

 

 

 

P.S:

  1. Performance period of Service Entry sheet not considered for accrual calculation
  2. Accrual will be calculated respectively based on
  3. a) Posting Date for Goods Receipt
  4. b) Last Change Date/Creation date of Service Entry sheet

2.4.   Posting of Service Entry Sheet Accruals

Fiori app “Schedule Accrual Jobs” will be used to post Service Entry sheet Accruals

 

Reversal of Accruals can be posted to together for Service Entry Sheet Accrual

 

 

3.  Configuration of SES – Accruals

SES Accrual configuration follow the below path in SPRO

SES – accruals require accrual engine configuration under Financial Accounting>Business Transactions>Accruals Management

3.1.     Basic Settings – Assign Company Codes

4.  Conclusion

Getting Service Entry Sheet accruals right in SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud isn’t just an accounting formality — it’s the backbone of accurate, timely financial reporting for service procurement. By pairing a clear SES approval process with the automated “Post Periodic Entries for Service Entry Sheet Accrual” job, businesses can confidently close their books knowing every accepted-but-unbilled service is captured in the right period. The result? Smoother month-ends, stronger compliance, and cleaner insights for smarter decision-making

entry.title: Purchase Price - RFQ vs PIR
entry.content:
Hey Experts,

The client has requested to use the Purchase Info Record (PIR) as the vendor quotation price. This would require updating the PIR with new conditions every time the material price changes.

However, my understanding is that the correct approach is to use the RFQ (Request for Quotation) and Quotation process instead of PIR. PIR is a master record and is not intended for dynamic price determination in purchase orders.

By using the RFQ process, we can establish a structured approval and maintenance hierarchy, allowing the purchase head to validate and maintain pricing more effectively.

Kindly advise on which approach is most appropriate.

This means the broker connection is not correctly set up (it probably throws a 401 or 403 error), but this is only visible in debug mode. Probably one of the prerequisite steps (registering SEMP profile or missing client username) was missed: https://help.sap.com/docs/sap-integration-suite/advanced-event-mesh/cap-plugin-for-sap-integration-suite-advanced-event-mesh

Try running your app with `DEBUG=messaging cds watch` to get verbose logging. If you want to step through the code to see more, you can also set line 4 to `const solace = require('solclientjs-debug')` to get readable code.

entry.title: Re: Issue with Onboarding of HA - Replication HANA system...
entry.content:
Dear Customer, 

Below is an example of an HA-HANA configuration in a system replication (HSR) scenario. The basic configuration for the HANA Data Supplier is as follows:

# your current primary HANA server
global.ini
[system_landscape_hostname_virtualization]
sldsystemhome = <physical host name of primary server>  
sldvirtdbhome = <virtual host name>

nameserver.ini
[sld]
enable=true
enable_virtdbhome = true

# your current secondary server
global.ini
[system_landscape_hostname_virtualization]
sldsystemhome = <physical host name of secondary server>
sldvirtdbhome = <virtual host name>

nameserver.ini
[sld]
enable=true
enable_virtdbhome = false

# your current tertiary server - and so on
global.ini
[system_landscape_hostname_virtualization]
sldsystemhome = <physical host name of tertiary server>
sldvirtdbhome = <virtual host name>

nameserver.ini
[sld]
enable=true
enable_virtdbhome = false

The parameter enable_virtdbhome will be automatically adjusted during a takeover. Never change that parameter manually. For more information, please see https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HANA_PLATFORM/6b94445c94ae495c83a19646e7c3fd56/7f6328c40e264b6fa32c1eb2425843c8.html?version=LATEST&locale=en-US.

After completing the configuration, register the HANA as instructed in the FRUN Prepare SAP HANA Database -> Data Supplier.

For troubleshooting purpose, please refer to the corresponding logs and files

> usr/sap/<SID>/HDB<nn>/<host>/trace/sldreg.log (records the HDBLCM SLD registration log)
> usr/sap/<SID>/HDB<nn>/<host>/trace/sldreg.xml (records the HANA associations to be sent to SLD or LMDB. payload

Best regards,
Vera Jiang

entry.title: Can the Business Partner(A2X) Api support the extension of roles
entry.content:
你好，

 

请问我们有这样的场景，需要使用外部系统调用Business Partner(A2X) 该api去实现role的扩展和新增。

 

举个例子：如现有一个business partner：DIGITS，已有role：customer company和customer sales organization，需要扩充其供应商的role：supplier company和supplier purchase organization。

 

我们已经尝试使用了如下的操作，但是未达到实际需要的效果，且role也没有扩展成功。 

 

1.客户已存在，把现有客户扩展成供应商

 


2.先ADD ROLE使用API
   /API_BUSINESS_PARTNER/A_BusinessPartner('{ i_req-req-businesspartner-businesspartner }')/to_BusinessPartnerRole
  此步ADD ROLE报错

 


3.ADD 供应商公司使用API 
  |/API_BUSINESS_PARTNER/A_SupplierCompany| &&
                      |(Supplier='{ i_req-req-businesspartner-businesspartner }',CompanyCode='{ suppliercompany-companycode }')|
 此步报错 METHOD 不存在

 


4.ADD采购组织使用API
 |/API_BUSINESS_PARTNER/A_Supplier('{ i_req-req-businesspartner-businesspartner }')/to_SupplierPurchasingOrg|
  此步报错 METHOD 不存在

 

以上，想了解该api能否支持已有客户扩展供应商的步骤及已有供应商扩展客户的步骤，感谢！

 

Frank

entry.title: Debugging in ABAP Development Tool (Part 1)
entry.content:
Introduction 

The Blog provides step by step guide on how to debug the report programs, classes and Function modules using Eclipse ADT (ABAP Development Tool). 
 
In this blog, we will be covering  
1.How to set the Toggle Breakpoint and the Soft Toggle Breakpoint. 
2.How to debug in multiple sessions 
3.How to check call stack 
4.How to debug update Function module 
5.How to set Watchpoint 
6.How to set Conditional breakpoint 
7.How to set user specific breakpoint 
8.How to Activate, Deactivate and Delete the Breakpoints 
9.How to Add new variable to observe the values in variables tab

Toggle Breakpoint (Regular/Hard Breakpoint): 

  • This is the standard breakpoint type, typically indicated by a blue icon in the editor margin. 
  • It serves to launch a new debugging session when the program execution reaches the line where it is set. 
  • If no debugger session is active, encountering a regular breakpoint will automatically trigger the debugger and stop execution at that point. 
    To set Toggle Breakpoint, we can right click on the left vertical bar as shown 

Soft Toggle Breakpoint: 

  • This is a specialized breakpoint type, typically indicated by a green icon in the editor margin. 
  • Crucially, a soft breakpoint cannot launch a new debugging session on its own. 
  • It becomes effective only when a debugging session is already active. If a debugger is already running (e.g., initiated by a regular breakpoint or external debugging), a soft breakpoint will then cause the execution to pause at its location. 
  • Soft breakpoints are often used in scenarios where you want to selectively stop execution within an already active debugging session, especially in situations with high-frequency calls or when you only want to debug specific parts of a larger process without repeatedly launching new sessions. 

To set the Soft Toggle Breakpoint, we can Right click on the left vertical bar as shown 

Debugging in multiple sessions 

By clicking on Application run (maximum 4 debugging sessions can be opened), we can debug the same program in multiple sessions 

After 4 debugging session if we again click on Application run it gives us error message at right edge of exclipse 

Debugging through Call Stack 
 
We can observe the events and navigate to the events in call stack at left side in Debug tab  

Debugging Update Function Module

Click on ABAP Debugger Action icon and then click on Update Debugging. 

Click on Ok to continue with update debugging. 

Setting the Watchpoint 

 Right click on the variable and then click on the Set Watchpoint 

we can observe the watchpoint for changed values 

 

Term 

Description 

Recent Value 

The value of the variable before the change that triggered the watchpoint. 

Current Value 

The value of the variable after the change, at the moment the debugger stops. 

For SY-INDEX = 12, the current value changed 

 

We can check the information whether watchpoint is reached or no 

Setting the Conditional Breakpoint 

Right click on the toggle breakpoint and then click on Breakpoint properties 

Set the condition and then click on Apply and close 

Before pressing F7  

After pressing F7 

Setting the User specific Breakpoint 

In debugging right click the toggle breakpoint and then click on Debugging Properties 

Select the User radio button and provide the username and then click on Apply and close

We can observe the u symbol on toggle breakpoint

Activating, Disabling (Deactivating) and Removing (Deleting) the Breakpoints 

 To deactivate the breakpoint, uncheck the checkbox 

To activate the breakpoint, check the unchecked checkbox

To remove the breakpoint, click on remove icon

Adding new variables such as SY-TABIX and SY-INDEX in Variables tab 

To add new variable in variable tab, click on Enter variable 

Enter the name of the variable (SY-INDEX) and press Enter 

 

 

Conclusion
Debugging in ADT isn’t just a technical exercise—it’s a strategic advantage. It transforms reactive troubleshooting into proactive insight. With its modern interface, modular object navigation, and precision tools like watchpoints and expression evaluators, ADT empowers developers to dissect complex logic, trace runtime behavior, and optimize code with surgical clarity.

entry.title: SAP Inside Track Kolkata 2025: A Technical Consultant's Journey Through Innovation, AI Use cases
entry.content:
As I sit down to consider the amazing experience of SAP Inside Track Kolkata 2025, which was conducted on August 2nd at the grand St. Xavier's University in New Town, I'm blessed to have such a huge sense of appreciation for the chance to have been included in such a motivating community event. Not only did I come as an avid SAP technical consultant but also as a coordinating volunteer for Track 2, and this provided me with an unrivalled insight into both the organizational expertise and technical expertise that made this event so exceptional.

The Perfect Setting for Innovation
St. Xavier's University Kolkata offered the perfect setting for our community meet. 

The commitment of the university to excellence was reflected in each and every aspect, from the state-of-the-art conference rooms to the stable network infrastructure underpinning our live demos and interactive sessions. Having been to many technical conferences, I can safely say that the venue contributed significantly to delivering the quality experience that SAP Inside Track Kolkata 2025 provided.

Track 2: Leading the Charge in Enterprise Transformation
Since I was the coordinating volunteer for Track 2, I had the privilege of collaborating very closely with some of the greatest minds in the SAP universe. Our track covered intelligent enterprise transformation and had the most innovative topics that are revolutionizing the way companies do business today.

RISE with SAP: Charting the Path to Intelligence
The day started with Debashis Majumder's engaging session on "RISE with SAP: Your Path to the Intelligent Enterprise". This session was all the more insightful because it highlighted how RISE with SAP is an end-to-end transformation package that brings together SAP S/4HANA Cloud, the SAP Business Technology Platform, and managed services to deliver an end-to-end digital transformation solution.

What I was most impressed by in this session was the way that RISE with SAP covers the entire range of enterprise requirements - from managed services and cloud infrastructure to business transformation as a service, as well as emerging technologies such as artificial intelligence, machine learning, and robotic process automation. As a technical consultant, I appreciated the conversation regarding the subscription model and the cost-effectiveness. This is especially important for the clients that I deal with who are looking at cloud migration strategies.

Joule Studio: Democratization of AI Agent Development
Koushik Goon's "What is Joule Studio and how it works?" presentation was completely captivating. Joule Studio, under SAP Build, is a game-changer in how we work with AI-powered business automation. The ability to design and deploy custom Joule agents and skills with easy-to-use drag-and-drop simplicity presents huge opportunities for companies to make AI solutions customized to their requirements.

The showcase of how developers can create AI agents that solve goal-oriented, complex business situations using dynamic planning and reasoning was impressive. The SAP and third-party application integration ensures the AI agents integrate well across various technology landscapes, a key requirement in the heterogeneous environments most companies use today.

Business AI and S/4HANA Integration
Sangeeta Majumder's presentation on "Business AI Use Cases with S/4HANA and SAP's AI Suite" offered real-world examples of how artificial intelligence is being integrated into central business processes. The session touched on real-world applications across business functions, from procurement optimization to financial reporting, illustrating quantifiable business value.

IBM's GenAI Assets and Platform Accelerators
The shared session between Aditi Chatterjee and Avijit Dhar on "Overview of IBM's Latest GenAI Assets and Process Accelerators on the IBM-SAP Platform" brought out the strategic significance of partner ecosystems in providing end-to-end AI solutions. Their observations about how IBM's generative AI assets are bundled with SAP platforms for speeding up business processes were especially insightful to understanding the wider AI picture beyond SAP's native capabilities.

Intelligent Invoicing Revolution
Arit Basu's talk on "Intelligent Invoicing using SAP Business Network" highlighted the real-world application of AI to daily business practices. The Intelligent Invoice Conversion functionality, leveraging Document Information Extraction (DOX) technology, to convert PDF and image-based invoice files into structured SAP Business Network invoices automatically, is a major step in accounts payable automation.

I was amazed by the demonstration of how machine learning algorithms automatically extract and map invoice information, with an easy-to-use interface for suppliers to create annotation rules for complicated invoice data. This product solves a genuine pain point that most of my customers experience in their procure-to-pay processes.

Next-Generation Field Mobility
The last Track 2 session, "Next-Gen Field Mobility: What's New in SAP Service and Asset Manager 2505" by Abhishek Chatterjee, discussed the transformation of mobile enterprise apps. The emphasis on growing field service functions with enhanced mobility solutions was a big hit with many of the participants who have asset-heavy businesses.

Networking: The Heart of Community Building
One of the greatest assets of SAP Inside Track Kolkata 2025 was the awesome networking opportunity it offered. As noted in numerous community forums, networking for SAP technical consultants is not merely a matter of swapping business cards - it's about creating enduring professional relationships that enable knowledge sharing, career growth, and access to out-of-the-way opportunities.

Throughout the event, I engaged in substantive discussions with:

Other ABAP colleagues who exchanged innovative coding methods and debugging approaches

S/4HANA transformation project peers working on similar functional consulting projects

Industry specialists who shared their vision on upcoming trends and best practices

Community leaders leading different SAP user groups in India

The afternoon fireside chat with community contributors was most informative, with participants from AWS User Group Kolkata, Kolkata WordPress Community, Databricks Community India, and SAP Community Kolkata. This inter-community collaboration session, led by Dipanwita Dutta, highlighted the need to bridge different technology communities to promote innovation and learning.

Keynote Insights and Industry Perspectives
The keynote sessions on the first day of the event established a strong tone for the whole event. SAP Community Senior Director Josh "Bluebeard" Bentley's speech highlighted the importance of community-based learning and collaboration in the SAP community. His perspectives on how the international SAP community keeps adapting and evolving with emerging technologies were inspiring and thought-provoking.

Srini Gottimukkula's keynote provided valuable industry perspectives on the current state and future direction of SAP technologies. The emphasis on intelligent enterprises and the role of AI-driven transformation aligned perfectly with the themes explored throughout our track sessions.

The welcome address by Reverend Dr. John Felix Raj, the Honourable Vice Chancellor of St. Xavier's University, beautifully captured the spirit of academic excellence and community collaboration that characterized the entire event.

Panel Discussions: Multiple Insights on Digital Transformation
The two panel sessions offered multiple perspectives on hot issues impacting the SAP community:

Panel Session 1 included industry experts such as Pankaj Lal, Prasun Dutta, Debashis Majumdar, Sarmistha Shanyal, and Tilak Kumar Dhar, moderated by Monimoy Kundu. The topics discussed ranged from practical SAP implementation strategy tips to lessons learned from actual projects.

Panel Session 2 represented a coming together of academic and industry viewpoints with speakers consisting of Prof. Amlan Chakrabarti, Dr. Indranil Mitra, Manoj Mishra, Dr. Saptarsi Goswami, Sabyasachi Biswas, and Srini Gottimukkula, moderated by Amitava Nag. The session offered useful insights into the convergence of academic research and industry usage in the SAP space.

Technical Deep Dives Across Multiple Tracks
Though I was mainly busy coordinating Track 2, I got a chance to visit sessions on other tracks during the break times:

Track 1 had extensive sessions on supply chain transformation using AI-driven intelligence, next-gen warehouse operations, and cloud ALM roadshow presentations. The focus on real-world applications and live demos made these sessions very useful.

Track 3 explored in-depth generative AI embedding within business strategy, SAP BTP highlights from the view of a Basis consultant, and best practices for SAP S/4HANA transformation. The session on "Leveraging SAP Conversational & Generative AI: Bengali Code Bot" was also very innovative and highlighted how AI can be localized for local needs.

Track 4 was data engineering and analytics, with sessions on Databricks, AWS and SAP integration, and foundation for Gen AI with SAP. These sessions gave a proper understanding of the overall ecosystem of technologies that go along with SAP solutions.

Key Takeaways for Technical Consultants
Being a SAP technical consultant, some key learnings that will have a direct effect on my work are:

1. AI Integration is Accelerating
The prolonged emphasis on Joule, AI agents, and intelligent automation in several sessions undoubtedly demonstrates that the integration of AI is no longer a consideration for the future - it's an existing imperative. Technical consultants must acquire skills in AI-powered SAP solutions to stay relevant.

2. Cloud-First Mindset is Mandatory
RISE with SAP and the other cloud-focused sessions validated that the sector has moved irrevocably towards cloud-first approaches. Cloud deployment models, migration approaches, and hybrid architectures are essential knowledge areas for technical consultants.

3. Low-Code/No-Code Platforms are Mainstream
The exhibition of Joule Studio's drag-and-drop feature and equivalent platforms in other sessions demonstrated that low-code development is going mainstream. Technical consultants must adopt these platforms alongside core development expertise.

4. Community Involvement Spur Learning
The networking and information exchange that were experienced during the event proved the tremendous benefit of an engaged community. Bi-weekly exposure to the SAP Community Network, local user communities, and events such as SAP Inside Track is crucial for career development.

Organizational Excellence Behind the Scenes
As a coordinating volunteer, I developed profound respect for the colossal effort that went into making this event happen. The SAP Inside Track Kolkata team showcased outstanding professionalism in handling:

Multi-track coordination with smooth transitions among sessions

The success of the event is a testament to the tireless organizers and volunteers who spent hundreds of hours on planning and execution. The SAP Community Network principles of knowledge sharing, collaboration, and support were manifested in every step of the event.

Looking Forward: The Future of SAP Community Events
SAP Inside Track Kolkata 2025 has established a new standard for community events in the region. The confluence of leading-edge technical content, industry expert views, hands-on demonstrations, and substantive networking opportunities provided an experience that will leave its mark on all participants.

The event proved that the Kolkata SAP community is not only consuming knowledge from the world but actively taking part in the worldwide SAP universe. The variety of speakers, the technical depth of conversations, and the quality of questions asked by participants reflected the maturity and professionalism of the local SAP community.

Conclusion: A Day That Transformed Perspectives
SAP Inside Track Kolkata 2025 was not just a conference - it was a celebration of learning, innovation, and community. Having worked in the SAP ecosystem for a few years now, I departed from the event rejuvenated with the potential that awaits us.

The technical learnings from sessions on AI, cloud transition, and intelligent automation will impact my client work directly. The working relationships forged during the day are already starting to bear collaborative opportunities. Above all, the feeling of community and commonality that pervaded the event was the reminder of why I decided to work in the SAP ecosystem.

To fellow SAP technical consultants who might be thinking of attending future SAP Inside Track events, I do not say enough good things about them. They offer a unique chance to:

Get up to date on the latest SAP technologies and industry trends

Meet peers, experts, and potential collaborators

Give back to the community through knowledge sharing and mentoring

Boost your professional image and career opportunities

Get hands-on experience with innovative solutions and best practices

The success of the SAP community is based on its collaborative nature and shared success. Examples such as SAP Inside Track Kolkata 2025 encapsulate these principles to perfection, generating environments where ideas are exchanged freely, bonds are forged, and innovation takes root.

I'm already counting down to SAP Inside Track Kolkata 2026 and the chance to extend this journey of discovery, sharing, and community building. Until that time, I invite all members of the SAP community to remain connected, keep up the learning, and keep adding to that shared knowledge that makes our ecosystem so rich and valuable.

#SAPInsideTrack #SAPCommunity #KolkataSAP #DigitalTransformation #RISEwithSAP #JouleStudio #SAPTechnicalnsultant #AIInBusiness #CloudTransformation

Heartfelt appreciation to the dream team who made every session, every connection, and every moment absolutely count!

@DataTherapist @Arka  @SohamBhKoL @Pritam991 @Kuntal_das @DEBADRITA_SAP @tunir_24 @titashshil 

@Sayontan_Das @Udity1211 @Diya_Dasupta @Raya_16 @ShreyanSAPO @adrijaMukherjee @SunnyMondal @soumajit_paul @GDas @Pritam_Paulm8  @AmittDubey @Kamallica @Rahul_Agarwal1 @Rajdeep_Dutta43 @Anurag_Dey98 @chandika_sarkar

If you went to SAP Inside Track Kolkata 2025 or any other SAP community event, I'd be happy to know your thoughts and opinions in the comments section below. Let's keep the dialogue going and community spirit burning!

entry.title: Experimenting with AI-Enhanced ABAP Development Setup
entry.content:
The Challenge: I Can't Achieve the Same AI-Assisted Flow in ABAP as in Other Languages

When I tested tools like SAP Joule, Amazon Q, Github CoPilot and others, I encountered what seemed to be two main limitations:

  1. Easy access to the ABAP platform file system or IDE workspace – In my testing, most AI assistants couldn't easily connect to the ABAP platform file system to work with actual source code. At least not as effortlessly and comprehensively as if these tools work with the local file system.
  2. Lack of understanding of SAP standards – I found that LLMs often struggled with ABAP-specific syntax and (internal) standard APIs.

The result in my case: broken code, unclear suggestions, wrong use of standard components leading to short dumps.

The Goal: Enable a Seamless, Productive AI Workflow for ABAP

Inspired by a full stack AWS CDK & React project I was recently working on, I tried transferring some of the workflows and framework conditions to my ABAP development practice. The result is an experimental set up that - so far - seems very promising to achieve a comparable development flow and seamless integration of AI coding assistants as I experienced in projects outside of the ABAP universe.

The set up utilizes existing open source and community based tools and combines them to help the AI coding assistant to work as intended. 

My Setup for Agentic ABAP Development

1. abapGit in the SAP backend

Crucial to sync ABAP code between the SAP dev system and a remote Git repository. I use the background option the keep the SAP system in sync with my local changes. The background option can be activated in the repo settings. Once activated, you can schedule a batch job of abapGit, which will then run the configured actions on the repo(s). In my case I configured the background auto pull function the keep the developments objects in the SAP dev system in sync with the changes I make locally & push to the remote.
Like this, the SAP dev system becomes more of a stage in a pipeline than a development environment.

auto pull option in abapGit repo 

2. A Remote Git Repository

It acts as the bridge between the SAP system and my local development environment. I only do changes in my local environment (see 3) and push them to the remote repo. The background configuration (see 1) ensures that the SAP system stays in sync with the remote. Currently there is nothing more happening here, but I'd like to enhance the set up with some actions once changes are pushed/ merged in the remote. Maybe only trigger the sync in (1) only when a pipeline successfully executes.

3. A Local Development Environment Powered by AI

On my local machine, I use Visual Studio Code enhanced by these key tools:

  • An AI coding assistant 
  • abaplint – The static code analysis tool by Lars Hvam to validate syntax and ensure code quality. This acts as a filter between AI output and real-world SAP code. The coding assistant can respond to the hints, warnings, errors given by the linter and therefore gets feedback whether it produces valid ABAP code, without the need for an actual ABAP platform underneath.
  • ADT MCP Server – A MCP server by Mario Andreschak that runs locally on my machine. It exposes SAP standard components to the AI engine. With this in place, LLMs can understand ABAP interfaces, function modules, and class signatures, etc. - making their suggestions much more relevant. I advise the LLM to use the first two parts of the Workflow ('searchObject' and 'getObjectSource') mentioned in the MCP repository to understand how it can get information about SAP standard objects.

Set Up Overview

 

 

What I've observed so far

My experience with this set up so far is really great. I mainly used it in a OO greenfield development, helping me to focus on software architecture and object composition and avoiding to deal with boilerplate code. I try writing to the AI assistant as with a development colleague, questioning my ideas and current problem solving approach. 
I also let the assistant implement complete parts of the solution after creating and evaluating a detailed development plan upfront. It works really well as long as the current 'feature scope' is not too large and the implementation plan is well described. 

This approach has given me what feels like a more tailored and extensible development experience compared to exclusively using the assistants mentioned at the beginning of this article without changing the complete set up.

--------------------------
This post was written with the help of GenAI.
Want to share your experiences with AI assisted coding? Get in touch!

entry.title: Re: RF Multi HU Picking
entry.content:
Hi @Eric_SAUTOT64 ,

it is the intended flow, that first all picks of a warehouse order are completed, and then they are dropped collectively off at the destination bin. If you always want to drop off the HU at the destination bin right after it has been picked, I see the following options:

  1. Define the warehouse order creation rules to have one warehouse task per warehouse order
  2. If the user navigates back (F7) after the first pick has been completed, I think the system should also ask the user if the remaining WTs shall be split to a new WO and if what has already been picked shall be dropped off the destination bin.

1) is probably the preferable approach and requires some customizing. 2) would be the lean solution, that requires the picker to know what to do.

Best regards,
Christian

entry.title: Re: PO Level UI Update
entry.content:
Hello @panchalal1023-5 

Based on the details provided, you are asking about UI enhancement for Purchase Orders. In Public Cloud, such changes must follow the key-user extensibility framework which is also the clean-core principle.

Yes, it is possible to add both a custom text field and a dropdown field on the PO screen using the standard extensibility tools. To implement this, you will require the following steps

First, add Custom Fields

  • Use the Custom Fields and Logic app.
  • Business Context: Purchase Order Header.
  • Create, One Text Field which is for free form notes and one Code List or Dropdown Field for category or reason.

Second, define Value Help for Dropdown

  • In the field properties, define a fixed code list such as Delivery Instructions, Payment Terms, Special Handling, etc.
  • Alternatively, create a custom business object if you need the dropdown values to be managed dynamically.

Third, expose the necessary Fields to UI

  • In the same app, enable the fields for usage in UI and select the relevant app → Manage Purchase Orders or Create Purchase Order Advanced.
  • This makes the fields appear on the PO header section.

Fourth is optional: Logic / Dependency

  • If you want the dropdown to influence or guide the text field input:
    • Implement a Custom Logic (BAdI) in the same business context.
    • Example: Pre-fill text field with a template note depending on dropdown category or validate that the text matches the expected category.

Finally, you need to transport or publish the changes to make them available system wide. If you are working across tenants, consider transporting via Software Collection.

Please note that successfully implementing will depend on the following:

  • Access to Custom Fields and Logic app.
  • PO must be extensible in the business context you select (header level is supported).
  • If dropdown values should be maintained centrally (instead of hard-coded), a Custom Business Object is needed.

Consult SAP Note 2212573  and Extending Purchase Orders for more information.

I hope this provides the desired result. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Purchase Price - RFQ vs PIR
entry.content:
Educate your client that the main difference between PIR and RFQ is one is master data and the other is transactional. The Best recommended approach in SAP is system to fetch all values from master data to transactional level and not vice versa. Having said that, though you have stated that the material prices change frequently and vendor quotations need validation, RFQ process is clearly more appropriate.

This is also taking into consideration, RFQ allows you to evaluate vendor quotes side by side, Approval option is there before PO creation. Most importantly, you can update the PIR automatically, from accepted quotations. As you know, in Quotations at item level tab, if you navigate to Item Overview tab, you can see a field "Info Update". If you tick this, SAP will update the PIR with the quotation price once the quotation is accepted.

You can also go through this blog by @shiv_mandowara

entry.title: Re: SAP Datasphere - Architecture and Lessons-Learned
entry.content:
Hello @haungo,
thanks a lot for your informative blog... and I really like your intro 🙂

Back in 2023 we directly started with a similar one to your 3rd approach on a 2-tier landscape
- 1 central space, from inbound up to fact views
- 4-5 spaces for LOBs containing the respective Analytic model

@Thibault_dockx
The reason for using several spaces for the AM is, it is the only way to hide these models for being seen by all users in SAC. Even if they cannot access them (due to missing DAC), at least they can see, what else exists. Some companies want to avoid that.

Coming to "the bad"... and I think there are still a few things:

1) it is bad that you have to associate the DACs in the fact view and not on the AM.
In that way it might be, you end up with 2-3 identical fact views, with different DACs. And if you still have some logic in the fact view with left outer joins or formulas etc., you always have to maintain all of them.
If the DAC was associated in the AM, there would be less effort to update those, when a fact view changes.

2) When you adjust e.g. a view, you never see the real consequence in terms of a provided list of objects, which need to be deployed again. I had it plenty of times that colleauges do some changes, but not all AMs are deployed again afterwards.

3) When you have stored objects into folders, after every deplyoment you find them back in "root" instead in the folder, where they have been stored before... Why do they lose that information?

4) Naming of the source system connections cannot be changed anymore. If you made the mistake to name your first connection to dev system like S4_DEV_ABAP... then you need to continue this name even in prod., even if you attached the prod. S4 to it. I think this should be stated more clearly, that the tech. name must be universal and the description related to the real system. I'm still confused today, if what I see is the tech. name or the description, since we made this mistake but realized it only after everything has been developed in Dev.-DSP, and we did not want to rework everything.

Would be nice to learn some more "bad" or "ugly" things from your sides 😉

BR, Martin

entry.title: Re: How to Define Posting Rules-Period Selection field？
entry.content:
PER + Average Rate is the clean, SAP-standard way to meet Chinese GAAP requirement (cash flow translated at average rate).

YTD + Reversal Doc Type is more of a technical workaround for cumulative postings (e.g., retained earnings, net income calc), not ideal for cash flow
